questions.query: If there is a communication failure on an IFR flight in IMC following a climb to the cleared flight planned level, the flight crew should:

Continue to the appropriate designated navigation aid serving the destination aerodrome, hold until the last reported EAT or until the ETA, then commence a descent.
Continue to the appropriate designated navigation aid serving the destination aerodrome, then immediately commence a descent.

options.text: for this type of call sign no abbreviated form is permitted.

questions.query: The word 'heavy' shall be added to the aircraft call sign :

If a radio transmission is received "now and then", it indicates readability:

Which elements shall all be read back to the controller?

options.text: runway in use, heading and speed instructions, SSR code, altimeter settings.
runway in use, heading and speed instructions, cloud base, altimeter settings and runway braking action.
clearances to land on, take-off from or cross the runway in use, RVR's.
clearance to land, clearance to enter the runway, expedite taxi, vacate the runway in use.

questions.query: Which of the following ATC messages need NOT be completely read back?

options.text: instructions to report when reaching a position or level.
information about QNH, QFE and Transition Level.

questions.query: The aircraft is at the holding point, ready for departure. The following clearance is given to the aircraft by the tower controller( TWR) : "(call sign) line up rwy 09 at (taxiway) November 5". State the correct phrase to read this back.

The flight crew receives the following ATC clearances and instructions: to descend to an altitude, to reduce speed, to fly a heading, the current Transition Level and the instruction to report ‘runway in sight’. Which of these items shall be read back in full?

options.text: all items must be fully read back.
all, but not to reduce the speed, the transition level and the instruction to report runway in sight
all, but not the transition level and the instruction to report runway in sight.
all, but not the instruction to report the runway in sight.

questions.query: A flight crew or pilot should terminate the read back of an instruction or clearance by:

options.text: taxi well behind the Jet, caution jet blast
behind the Piper twin on final, line up rwy 27 behind.
line up rwy 27, be ready for immediate departure.
Behind the company airaft on the right, push back approved
report turning baseleg, you are number 2, number 1 is the high-wing turning final.
caution wake turbulence, runway 06 cleared for takeoff., wait for 2 minutes

questions.query: ATC asks you during flight about your 'flight conditions'. The correct answer is:

options.text: if flying VMC above minimums in visibility and distance to clouds.
if flying IMC when flying above clouds.

questions.query: If you are asked: "report flight conditions", this means:

options.text: report significant weather conditions such as turbulent wind, poor visibility, heavy rains.
indicate if you are flying VFR or IFR
indicate if visibility is sufficient for landing (RVR).
indicate whether you are flying IMC or VMC

options.text: after receiving ATC clearance to cross that runway.
prior permission is only required when low visibility procedures apply.
you may continue to taxi, cross the runway, unless a stop-bar is red or low visibility procedures apply.

questions.query: How do you request permission to cross a runway and continue to your departure runway when you are at an intersection of an intermediate runway?

options.text: when holding in front of the intermediate runway:request cross runway (number).
when on the parking stand/gate:request taxi runway (number).

options.text: go around and join a left circuit.

options.text: report over the blocks[prepare for possible go around].

questions.query: On final a pilot decides not to land but to perform a missed approach instead. How should this be reported to the Tower?
On final a pilot decides not to land but to perform a missed approach instead. How should this be reported to the Tower?

options.text: a taxi clearance to the red line between movement area and manoeuvring area.
an instruction to taxi up to and hold not closer to a runway than specified (i.e.holding point).
to hold position where you are now to avoid an incident or accident.
remain on the runway and expect delay for the takeoff clearance.

options.text: (condition) lining up runway xx (repetition of the condition).

questions.query: A Low Pass is:

options.text: fly past the control tower or other observation past for the purpose of visual inspection by persons on the ground.
a Low Instrument Approach with an agreed minimum level (e.g. “not below 300 ft.”).
a low circuit below the published circuit altitude.

questions.query: In the visual circuit of a controlled aerodrome the Tower instructs the pilot to “extend downwind”. Which circuit procedure must the pilot perform?

options.text: an approach whereby one make a 270 degree turn on the base leg.
an approach where one aborts an IFR approach at the base turn in order to make a “circling approach”.
a procedure whereby in the traffic circuit one turns to base leg abeam the runway threshold.
an IFR procedure where one is vectored in order to intercept a “short line-up” for the instrument approach (ILS).

questions.query: At a controlled aerodrome, right hand downwind in the circuit shall be reported:

options.text: always in the right hand circuit, except when this circuit is already published in the AIP as a right hand circuit.
always when in a right hand circuit.
only when also a left hand circuit is active for the same runway.
all of the above (a,b and c) are correct.

questions.query: When in a VFR traffic circuit (VMC) a pilot receives his/her landing number from ATC, this number :

options.text: should be acknowledged by means of "roger", followed by call sign.

indicates the flight is performed under “special VFR” for separ­ation purposes.
should always be read back to ATC.

questions.query: A "Go Around":

options.text: is only initiated by ATC in case landing is unsafe.
means that the pilot has to make a 360 degree turn.
means that the approach is discontinued shortly before touchdown.

you are to join downwind when you are mid-runway.
that there is no regular downwind leg baseleg must be joined mid-runway.
that the pilot must fly a 'two-seventy" to join the base leg.

options.text: on 243 MHz at first instant the distress occurs

questions.query: The safety of a aircraft or even another vehicle, or of some person on board or in sight is threatened, but no immediate assistance is required. Which procedure shall be initiated by a flight crew?

options.text: concerning the safety of an aircraft or other vehicle or of some person on board or within sight, but which does not require immediate assistance.
concerning the safety of an aircraft or other vehicle or of some person on board or within sight, which requires immediate assistance on the ground.
of being threatened by serious and/or imminent danger and of requiring immediate assistance.

questions.query: You are flying over a lake and you see a ship on fi­re. You report this in the following manner:

options.text: MAYDAY MAYDAY MAYDAY on the operational frequency.

questions.query: A STAR consist of :

a published route and speed limitation and ends at the FAF.

questions.query: On a SRA (Surveillance Radar Approach) service, the pilot is given: (1) distances from touchdown. (2) advisory speeds (3) azimuth instructions. (4) advisory altitude or height information.

an approach for an instrument runway which is abandoned as soon as the runway is in sight, to make a visual straight-in landing on a different runway.
an instrument approach where one decides at the decision height to abandon the approach.
an ILS approach which is abandoned because one has strayed outside the localizer beam.

questions.query: IFR aircraft may request permission to make a visual approach only when the:

options.text: flight crew can maintain visual reference to terrain.

questions.query: To indicate to Approach Control that an aircraft is correctly positioned on the centerline of an ILS approach, the term the flight crew should use is:

options.text: an instrument approach with more than one “dot” below the ideal approach path.
an approach along or parallel to a runway descending to an agreed minimum level.
a circling approach below the MDA (Minimum Descent Altitude).
a low visual circuit, also called low downwind.

questions.query: During a procedure turn over an NDB to execute an ILS approach, what is the term used to describe the first passage over the beacon?

options.text: visibility must be VMC, the aircraft must be in level flight.
the aircraft may be in level flight or descending and an approach clearance must have been received.
the aircraft must be in level flight and an approach clearance must have been received.
the aircraft may be in level flight or descending, visibility must be VMC, an approach clearance must have been received.

questions.query: You are flying IFR during VMC and experience communication failure. How do you act when following general ICAO rules?

options.text: continue to fly VMC and land at the nearest suitable aerodrome.
since it is an IFR flight, continue to the flight plan destination.
divert to the alternate airport when that is nearer than the destination.
return to the aerodrome you departed from if you are not beyond the half-way point. Remain in VMC.

questions.query: An aircraft being vectored away from its flight-planned route or having been directed by ATC to proceed offset using RNAV without a specific limit, and then experiencing communications failure, should:

options.text: maintain the last acknowledged heading and speed for 7 minutes and then rejoin the current flight plan route.
perform a so-called 'dog-leg' procedure to regain the filed flight plan route.
take the most direct ATS route to the planned destination, taking into account the the applicable minimum safe altitude.
rejoin the current flight plan route no later than the next significant point, taking into consideration the applicable minimum flight plan altitude.

questions.query: If a normal instrument approach procedure is conducted following communications failure, a landing should be completed within………&...
You have a sticking transmitter. In practice this means:

options.text: you are nevertheless still able to receive clearances.
you are able to give position reports using "blind transmissi­ons".

questions.query: If an aerodrome control tower reports runway conditions as having “WATER PATCHES”, this means that:

options.text: the runway is damp there is no risk of aquaplaning. Braking action may be reduced.
there is no risk of aquaplaning, unless the runway is reported as “slippery when wet”as well.
there is no risk of aquaplaning, unless also reported as “WET”.

questions.query: If an aerodrome control tower reports runway conditions as being “WET”, the pilot should assume that:

options.text: there is no risk of aquaplaning, unless the runway is reported as “slippery when wet”.
there is no risk of aquaplaning, unless also reported as “Grooved”.

questions.query: If an aerodrome control tower or ATIS reports runway conditions as "standing water", the flight crew should assume that:
You receive a TCAS instruction telling you to climb. What must you immediately say to ATC ?

options.text: TCAS climb, leaving FL XXX climbing to FL XXX.

questions.query: The crew had to make a sudden level change because of a TCAS/ACAS warning . The situation is now resolved. How should a flight crew report to ATC that the ACAS "clear of conflict" has been given and the crew are starting their return to their original level?

options.text: leaving TCAS level, returning to flight plan level.

questions.query: The crew had to make a sudden level change because of a TCAS warning followed by a climb or descent instruction. The situation is resolved and the flight is back at the cleared level. How shall they report to ATC that they have returned to their cleared level?
What does 'RA' stand for in a TCAS RA when the crew is told to climb?
The phrase ‘take off’ is used only when an aircraft is cleared for take off or when cancelling a take off clearance. At all other times the following 2 words or phrases shall be used:
If it is uncertain whether the pilot can comply with an ATC clearance, the controller will use:
When the ATC instruction is: “(call sign) stop immediately (repeat call sign) stop immediately”, then the prescribed read back should be:
State the correct combination of the two phraseologies ATC may choose from to instruct the pilot to follow a specific track after take-off:

options.text: track extended centre line or: climb straight ahead
track extended centre line or: continue runway heading.
continue runway heading or: continue runway track.
continue runway heading or: extend take-off leg.

questions.query: When you are told to stop suddenly during ground manoeuvring the instruction will be:
During ground movements, ATC instructs a flight crew: "(caution), taxi slower". The read back of the crew should be:
You are being vectored by a radar service. On completion, the controller will say:
You have been intercepted by a (foreign) military aircraft and you have established two-way radio contact with its crew. How do you indicate that you are lost?
During approach you receive the following phrase from ATC, “Continue approach" which means:

options.text: you can continue the approach to the OM or the 4-mile final point.
you can continue the approach to final.
you can continue the approach to the FAP.
you can continue the approach to the runway but you are not cleared to land.

questions.query: During an IFR approach to a controlled aerodrome the relevant ATIS code l­e­t­ter should be mentioned to:
The instruction "omit position reports" means:
When ATC instructs the crew on an IFR flight to fly parallel to the left or the right of the desired track this will be instructed using:

options.text: turn left /right X degrees to the left/right.
track extended centre line (to the left or to the right).

questions.query: Sometimes a flight crew is requested to select a frequency when it is intended that the ATS unit will initiate communications soon and the crew should not contact them. This is requested by the ATS unit as follows:"............ (unit call sign) (frequency):
To acknowledge relevant traffic information received from ATC, the crew should transmit:

What phrase will ATC unit use to instruct a flight (level, climbing or descending) to be at or pass a certain sginificant point at a certain assigned level? "(call sign aircraft), ..................(significant point) AT (or ABOVE, or BELOW(level XX):
The ATC instruction to climb out after departure and 'Track Extended Centre Line" means:

options.text: intercept the outbound track of the radio beacon servicing that runway.
maintain the runway track correct for wind.
maintain the runway heading do not correct for wind.
climb out on the published track of the SID.

questions.query: When ATC allows a flight crew to perform an action without a restriction as to when and it is up to the crew to commence the action, this will be approved by ATC stating:
What phrase will ATC use to warn a flight crew of the wake vortices of near-by or preceding heavy aircraft?
When ATC needs to correct or amend a CPDLC message that was sent, how will ATC inform a flight crew by radio?

options.text: disregard CPDLC (clearance or message), break, (reclearance or revised message).
cancel CPDLC clearance, acknowledge (reclearance or revised message).
due CPDLC failure (clearance or message) incorrect, confirm (reclearance or revised message).
due CPDLC failure cancel (clearance or message), advise ready to copy (reclearance or revised message).

questions.query: What is SSR an abbreviation of ?
SRA stands for:
The abbreviation EAT stands for:
The acronym ACARS stands for:
The abbreviation ADS stands for:
State the correct definition of a visual approach.

options.text: An approach executed by an IFR flight at the destination if the conditions are equal to or better than the VMC minima.
An approach where only part of an instrument procedure is flown with the remaining part of the flight flown visually with reference to terrain.
Flying a VFR traffic circuit in IMC conditions.
Landing in VMC on an IFR flight after the approach clearance has been received and acknowledged.

questions.query: A low approach is:

options.text: an instrument approach maximally one "dot" below the ideal approach path.
an approach along or parallel to a runway descending to an agreed minimum level.
a circling approach below the MDA (Minimum Descent Altitude).
an instrument approach path that descends below the required glide path of 3 degrees resulting in an 'undershoot'.

questions.query: An aeronautical station is:

options.text: an airborne station in the aeronautical mobile service.
a land station in the aeronautical mobile service, but may be located on a platform at sea.
a radio beacon or navaid on the ground or on a platform at sea.
an automated broadcast service of current, routine information to arriving and departing aircraft.

questions.query: What is 'Air-Ground' communication?

options.text: two-way radio communication between aircraft stations or locations on the surface of the earth.
one-way communication from the aeronautical station to a station or location on the ground surface.
the principle of direction finding using the appropriate VHF frequencies.
listening to an automatic terminal broadcast from an aircraft.

questions.query: Read Back is:

options.text: the procedure whereby the receiving station (usually the aircraft) repeats a message or relevant part of that message to the sending station in order to obtain confirmation of correct reception.
the procedure whereby the audio feed-back of the station receiving the signal disturbs reception of the message.
the request from air traffic control to verify information with another station, such as the airline operator or owner.
the request from a flight crew to the ground station to repeat the original message because it was not properly received.

questions.query: DUPLEX communication is a method in which:

options.text: telecommunication between two stations can take place in both directions simultaneously.
telecommunication between two stations can take place in only one direction at a time.
a message is received via a navigation aid such as a VOR (VHF radio station) and the message is sent through another channel.
a message is received through one radio set and the answer is transmitted using a navigation aid such as a VOR (VHF radio station).

questions.query: SIMPLEX communication is a method in which:

options.text: telecommunication between two stations can take place in one direction at a time.
telecommunication between two stations can take place in both directions simultaneously.
a message is sent to aircraft using a navigation aid such as a VOR (VHF radio station).
a message is received through one radio set and the answer is transmitted using a navigation aid such as a VOR (VHF radio station).

questions.query: State the correct definition of "Broadcast".

options.text: a transmission of information relating to air navigation that is not addressed to specific station or stations.
inter pilot air-to-air communication engaged in flights over remote areas out of range of VHF stations to exchange necessary operational information and to solve operational problems.

questions.query: Heading 100 shall be pronounced: "Heading........
heading 270 shall be pronounced: "heading....................."
When a pilot reports an ACAS (TCAS) RA, the controller shall not try to modify the aircraft's flight path until the pilot reports:
